content: The "Travel America Now Act of 2001" may be cited as the short title for this Act. The findings section is included in the Act. Prior to September 11, 2001, over 19 million Americans were employed in travel and travel-related jobs, with an annual payroll of $171.5 billion. The travel and tourism industry in the US grew to be the third largest industry in terms of retail sales, with expenditures exceeding $582 billion in 2000. This industry also generated over $99.6 billion in tax revenues and created a $14 billion trade surplus for the US in the same year. In 2000, the travel and tourism industry in the US generated over $99.6 billion in tax revenues and created a $14 billion trade surplus. Post 9/11, efforts are being made to ensure safe travel and maintain traveler confidence. Urgent measures are needed to support workers and generate cash flow. Increased consumer spending on travel and tourism is crucial for the US economy's revival. The public should be encouraged to travel for both personal and business reasons to support workers and boost cash flow in the industry. Increased consumer spending on travel and tourism is essential for revitalizing the United States economy. The American public should be encouraged to travel for personal and business reasons to keep working people employed and stimulate cash flow to help the economy rebound. The Internal Revenue Code of 1986 is amended to include a new section on Personal Travel Credit to encourage travel for economic stimulation. The new section of the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. The maximum credit is $500 for individuals and $1,000 for joint filers. Qualified personal travel expenses are defined as reasonable expenses related to personal travel. The new section of the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. Qualified personal travel expenses include reasonable expenses for travel and lodging, excluding expenses for meals, entertainment, amusement, or recreation. The new section of the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. A qualifying personal trip involves travel within the United States, with the farthest destination being at least 100 miles from the taxpayer's residence, an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, and taken on or after the specified date. The new section of the Internal Revenue Code allows individuals to claim a credit for qualified personal travel expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. A qualifying personal trip involves travel within the United States, with the farthest destination being at least 100 miles from the taxpayer's residence, an overnight stay at a commercial lodging facility, and taken on or after the specified date. The term "qualified personal travel" excludes travel expenses deductible in connection with a trade or business or income-producing activity. The term 'commercial lodging facility' includes hotels, motels, resorts, rooming houses, or campgrounds. No credit is allowed under this section to individuals eligible for a deduction under section 151 by another taxpayer in the same calendar year. The amendment to section 274 of the Internal Revenue Code allows for a temporary increase in the deduction for meal and entertainment expenses, changing the limitation from 50 percent to 100 percent for expenses incurred between the enactment date and January 1, 2002. This amendment applies to taxable years ending after the enactment date of the Act. SEC. 5. Net operating loss carryback for travel and tourism industry. Net operating loss carryback for travel and tourism industry for taxable years including September 12, 2001, to before January 1, 2002, allows losses to be carried back for 5 years. The net operating loss carryback provision allows travel and tourism industry losses from the period after September 12, 2001, and before January 1, 2002, to be carried back for up to 5 years. Travel or tourism business includes activities related to commercial transportation, lodging, airport operation, and transportation services. The CARES Act allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for up to 5 years, covering activities such as commercial transportation, lodging, airport operation, travel agent services, convention facilities, and other services specified by the Secretary. The CARES Act allows travel and tourism industry losses to be carried back for up to 5 years, covering activities such as convention, trade show, entertainment facilities, and other specified services as determined by the Secretary. Losses are treated similarly to specified liability losses for tax purposes, and taxpayers can elect a 5-year carryback period for eligible losses. The CARES Act allows taxpayers to elect a 5-year carryback period for specified liability losses, which must be made by the due date for filing the tax return and is irrevocable once elected. The election for a 5-year carryback period for specified liability losses must be made by the tax return due date and is irrevocable once chosen. Additionally, regulations allow a taxpayer with a travel or tourism loss to credit it against taxable income earned during the carryback period by any member of a controlled group of corporations. The amendments allow a 5-year carryback for travel or tourism losses to be credited against taxable income of a controlled group of corporations. Effective for taxable years before, on, or after the enactment of the Act. The Act is based on Congress's power to levy taxes as outlined in article I, section 8 of the US Constitution.
